source:
Lab 6: Decision Trees and Unsupervised Learning

**Goal:** In this notebook we are going to apply machine learning methods to train statistical models and explore new methods of inference and prediction. We will focus on decision trees a Supervised Learning model that can support both regression (learn continuous labels) and classification (learn discrete labels), and Unsupervised Learning. In particular, we will continue practicing with the Python library Scikit-learn and play with: - Decision Trees
- Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
- Clustering (K-means)
The goals of this notebook are to test the application of decision trees methods and unsupervised learning methods to structured datasets; to interpret the output of such models; and to apply model validation methods.

Decision Trees

We start by covering the application of Decision Trees. First, we will apply the Scikit-learn Estimator API, as we discussed in previous Labs (see Lab 5), to fit a Decision Tree that learns to classify iris flours into classes setosa, versicolor, and virginica. To review materials related with Decision Trees please check Lecture 6 slides, Chapter 8.1 of the [ISLR book](https://www.statlearning.com) and Chapter *In-Depth: Decision Trees and Random Forests* of the [PDSH book](https://jakevdp.github.io/PythonDataScienceHandbook/05.08-random-forests.html).

# General imports
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Data processing
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split

#Import Iris dataset loader
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris

#Import decision tree model and a function that helps plotting the tree.
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier, plot_tree

iris = load_iris() # Loads the iris dataset
iris.feature_names #prints the features (columns names)

# We only take the two corresponding features: petal length and width (columns 2 an 3)
X = iris.data[:, [2,3]]
y = iris.target

# Train
decision_tree = DecisionTreeClassifier().fit(X,y)

plt.figure(figsize=(12,12))
plot_tree(decision_tree, filled=True, feature_names=['p-len','p-width'], class_names=iris.target_names.tolist())
plt.show()
**Q1: What is the meaning of *gini*, *samples* and *value* in the plot above?**

**Q2: Write code that applies a decision tree with a depth of 2 to the iris dataset as above**

Hint: Check the lecture 6 slides or [the scikit-learn decision tree documentation](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.tree.DecisionTreeClassifier.html#sklearn.tree.DecisionTreeClassifier).

# We only take the two corresponding features: petal length and width (columns 2 an 3)
X = iris.data[:, [2,3]]
y = iris.target

# MISSING LINE: decision_tree = ...


plt.figure(figsize=(12,12))
plot_tree(decision_tree, filled=True, feature_names=['p-len','p-width'], class_names=iris.target_names.tolist())
plt.show()
**Q3: Write code that applies a decision tree to the iris dataset as above but for petals (columns 0 and 1)**

# We only take the two corresponding features: petal length and width (columns 2 an 3)
# MISSING LINE: X = ...

y = iris.target

# MISSING LINE: decision_tree = ...


plt.figure(figsize=(12,12))
plot_tree(decision_tree, filled=True, feature_names=['s-len','s-width'], class_names=iris.target_names.tolist())
plt.show()
**Q4: Compare the sizes of the trees, which features are more relevant/important to classify iris data?**
**Q5: Write the code that applies a decision tree to all columns of the iris dataset**

# We only take the two corresponding features: petal length and width (columns 2 an 3)
# MISSING LINE: X = ...

y = iris.target

# MISSING LINE: decision_tree = ...


plt.figure(figsize=(12,12))
plot_tree(decision_tree, filled=True, feature_names=['s-len','s-width','p-len','p-width'], class_names=iris.target_names.tolist())
plt.show()

**Q6: Given the tree above, how important are the sepals to identify iris?**

Tip: count the nodes using petal features in the tree

Now we will put it all together to train and test a decision tree.
Below we split the data into train and test sets, we train a Decision Tree and use it to classify the test set (df_test). 
This is used to computer the accuracy of the model

from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix, ConfusionMatrixDisplay

# 1. Arrange data into a fetures matrix and target vector; split data in train and test set
# As we are not tuning hyperparameters, for now it suffices to slit data in train and test (and skip validate)
df_train, df_test, Y_train, Y_test = train_test_split(
    X, 
    y, 
    test_size = 0.3, 
    random_state=12345,
    stratify=y)

# 2. Choose model and hyperparameters
decision_tree = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth=2)

# 4. Fit model to data
decision_tree.fit(df_train,Y_train)

# 3. Predict labels for unknown data and evaluate
y_pred = decision_tree.predict(df_test)

cm = confusion_matrix(Y_test, y_pred, labels=decision_tree.classes_)
disp = ConfusionMatrixDisplay(confusion_matrix=cm,display_labels=iris.target_names.tolist())
disp.plot()
plt.show()
**Q7: Compute for class versicolor the Sensitivity, Specificity, False Positive Rate, and Precision for the previous confusion matrix.**

Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

We now will cover the application of PCA. First, we will apply the Scikit-learn Estimator API, as we discussed in previous Labs (see Lab 5), to fit a PCA that finds the principal components in the wine datasets. Although the wine dataset is used for classification, PCA don't take into account the classes, it is an unsupervised learning method. To review materials related with PCA please check Lecture 6 slides and the check the Scikit-learn [PCA documentation](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.decomposition.PCA.html).

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

from sklearn.datasets import load_iris, load_wine
from sklearn.decomposition import PCA

# Loads the wine dataset
wine = load_wine()
X = wine.data
y = wine.target

The code below performs PCA on the dataset (X, y) above. It summarizes the iris data with 2 principal components (just as we saw in Lecture 6). Finally, it plots the resulting data with a scatter plot, along the 2 principal components.

n_components = 2
pca = PCA(n_components=n_components)
X_pca = pca.fit_transform(X)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 10))
ax.scatter(X_pca[y==0, 0], X_pca[y==0, 1], cmap="tab10",lw=3, alpha=0.6, s=200)
ax.scatter(X_pca[y==1, 0], X_pca[y==1, 1], cmap="tab10",lw=3, alpha=0.6, s=200)
ax.scatter(X_pca[y==2, 0], X_pca[y==2, 1], cmap="tab10",lw=3, alpha=0.6, s=200)

plt.show()
The code below creates a Scree Plot to evalute how many components you need to explain most of data Variance.

pca = PCA()
X_pca = pca.fit_transform(X)

PC_values = np.arange(pca.n_components_) + 1
plt.plot(PC_values, pca.explained_variance_ratio_, 'ro-', linewidth=5)
plt.title('Scree Plot')
plt.xlabel('Principal Component')
plt.ylabel('Proportion of Variance Explained')
plt.show()
**Q8 How many components you need to explain most of data Variance? How to interpret that plot?**
**Q9 Repeat the PCA examples but now use the Iris dataset**

Clustering

We now will cover the application of K-Means, a clustering method. First, we will apply the Scikit-learn Estimator API, as we discussed in previous Labs (see Lab 5), to fit a K-means that finds the K clusters from the data. To review materials related with Clustering and K-means please check Lecture 6 slides.
from sklearn.cluster import KMeans

We now use the data along the 2 principal components above (X_pca) to perform a k-means with k=3. We plot the results in a scatter plot, where colors of points correspond the the derived clusters. Then we print the position of the centers of each cluster found through k-means.**

Tip: check the Scikit-learn [KMeans documentation](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.cluster.KMeans.html) learn to understand how to access clusters' centers and labels based on clusters.

kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=3, random_state=0).fit(X_pca)
kmeans.labels_

labels = kmeans.predict(X_pca)

print(kmeans.cluster_centers_)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 10))
ax.scatter(X_pca[:,0], X_pca[:,1], c=kmeans.labels_, lw=3, alpha=0.6, s=200)
plt.show()
**Q10: Repeat the KMeans with a different number of clusters and then with another dataset.**
